feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A metadata tag is not a tangible entity; it exists as an abstract label or marker.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Tags can vary by context, application, or data.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Not inherently perceptible outside of representation.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — Exists in data structures, not physical materials.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — A tag itself doesn't exhibit passive physical behavior.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Tags are created to classify, mark, or organize data intentionally.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — Does not generate output by itself.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Tags are descriptors, not state machines.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Accessed through systems, not inherently interactive.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — While used in systems, the tag itself is a unit of abstraction, not a subsystem.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Tags require context to function meaningfully.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Tags support metadata frameworks but are not critical individually.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Tags symbolically reference categories or attributes.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Tags convey meaning about data.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Tags often follow naming rules, schemas, or ontologies.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Tags may be part of structured vocabularies or hierarchies.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Tags can guide system or user behavior (e.g., filtering, formatting, access).
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — While related to metadata, the tag itself is not self-referential.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Tags are not inherently time-based.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Tags acquire meaning only within a given schema, system, or domain.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Metadata schemes and tagging vocabularies are socially negotiated.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Commonly established by institutions, platforms, or standards bodies.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Tags label data, not people.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Rarely enforced legally, though schema adherence may be required.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Standard tagging practices are teachable.
feedback.Visible: Included — Tags are visible to users, systems, or developers depending on access.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — The interpretation of a tag varies by system or domain.
feedback.Widely known: Included — The concept of tagging is pervasive across platforms and domains.

encoding_notes: A metadata tag is a symbolic abstraction used to structure and describe data. It is a communicative and behavior-guiding unit designed for context-dependent interpretation within data systems. Though essential to metadata infrastructure, it is not inherently physical or functional—it is an informational construct embedded in human-made logical and social frameworks.
